<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_bus_register:
```c
int metal_bus_register(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	if (!bus || !bus->name || !strlen(bus->name))
		return -EINVAL;
	if (metal_bus_find(bus->name, NULL) == 0)
		return -EEXIST;
	metal_list_init(&bus->devices);
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.bus_list, &bus->node);
	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "registered %s bus\n", bus->name);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_bus_register:
int metal_bus_find(const char *name, struct metal_bus **result)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.bus_list, node) {
		bus = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_bus, node);
		if (strcmp(bus->name, name) == 0 && result) {
			*result = bus;
			return 0;
		}
	}
	return -ENOENT;
}

explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for indirect or direct self-calls under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 because they are simple checks, standard library calls, or straightforward non-calling constructs: - The pointer and empty-name validation (if (!bus || !bus->name || !strlen(bus->name))) are simple conditions; strlen is a standard library routine and not expected to call back into project functions. - The explicit return statements (return -EINVAL; return -EEXIST; return -ENOENT; return 0;) are terminal actions, not function calls that could recurse. - The metal_container_of usage is a compile-time pointer arithmetic macro (no function call). - The strcmp usage inside the loop is a standard library comparison (it does not invoke user callbacks). These constructs therefore do not by themselves create direct or indirect recursion and need not be further investigated for Rule 17.2.
